author: ajsutton
content: I think there was an eth1 node configuration issue which has caused pyrmont to not agree on a new eth1 block.  Config has now been fixed but it will basically reset the clock on getting a vote through.

author: ajsutton
content: Looks like voting is back on track for eth1 now so things will get moving again. I don't have a view of how many more votes are required yet.

author: ajsutton
content: Normally I look at the data in a chaind database but I don't have one for pyrmont at the moment.  I ran `curl http://localhost:5051/eth/v1/debug/beacon/states/head | jq .data.eth1_data` against Teku to find the current eth1 block that was recognised.

author: ajsutton
content: You have to go through each block checking what they're voting for to calculate how much longer before a new block is ready.  chaind makes that a simple SQL query but its painful otherwise.

author: ajsutton
content: I have checked a few blocks to confirm the different groups were agreeing and they all now seem to be voting for https://goerli.etherscan.io/block/0xd4a3bf08eb6b22be896e430e9d8c9ccd2c1369fe57eab3ddb5702c775c7dc9af

author: protolambda
content: For now you can ignore milagro bls dependency. You can switch back and forth between py-ecc and milagro actually (there's a variable in the bls module to redirect to different bls library), and it's only really used to run state transitions. Or disable it directly by changing the "bls_enabled" flag in the bls module, if you only deal with trusted data anyway.
